organism is a regular part of annual gynecologic exams at the Clinic.
Even though the symptoms of this infection are often mild or even
nonexistent, the consequences of untreated infections can be
devastating, especially for women. This organism can gain access
to the uterus and fallopian tubes, setting up an intense inflammation
that can result in scarring which leads to infertility and/or an increased
risk for ectopic pregnancy (an abnormal pregnancy in which the fertilized egg grows in the fallopian tube rather than the uterus.) Fortunately, ther are several inexpensive tests that can identify individuals
even if thay have no symptoms. All of these techniques are available
through the Student Health Clinic.
Once an infection is detected, treatment is relatively simple. A student need only take doxycycline, tetracycline, or erythromycin for
seven to ten days. Successful treatment, and limitation of spread of
this organism, requires notification of all recent sex partners. Unfortunately, infection does not confer immunity: one can be infected

The Student Conservation
Association is a nonprofit
education organization founded in 1957 to enable young
people to participate in the
management of wilderness
areas and natural resources.
More than 15,000 young men
and women have participated
in SCA's programs during the
past 32 years.
Programs are carried out in
cooperation with federal agencies including the National
Park Service, the U.S. Forest
Service, the Bureau of Land
Management, and the U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service. The
SCA also contributes to conservation efforts at many state
and local natural resource
areas across the country.

by Eric Ruck
Throughout history, and
especially in the '50s, people
have asked the question, why do
fools fall in love? Why indeed?
Blessed with a university full of
experts on a variety of
disciplines, we took this question
to the streets, to Ames, Gilman
and Shaffer halls, and other
places less mentionable so we
could bring this feature to you for
Valentine's Day. The following
are the best responses. Enjoy.
"I think it's a defense against
ego boundaries. When you grow
up you realize that you have
limitations, that what you think
isn't what other people think. It's
an attempt at changing that.
When you fall in love you slacken
ego boundaries.
Falling in love is a way of connecting yourself with the world."
—Walter Harley, psychology
grad student

A decade ago, warts were considered a problem mainly because
they were unsightly. However, recent research has established a link
between HPV infection and the development of cancer of the cervix
in women. This is not to say that any woman with genital warts will
develop cervical cancer. Rather, sexually active women with HPV
infection appear to be at higher risk for developing cervical cancer
than sexually active women who do not have such an infection. The
magnitude and nature of the risk has yet to be worked out. A piece
of the puzzle appears to be that certain strains of HPV that cause
genital warts have the capability of transforming normal cells into
cancerous cells whereas other strains of genital HPV do not. It is
also likely that other factors—as yet unidentified—play a role.
Any male who has any concerns that he has genital warts should
seek care at the Student Health Clinic. Those who have been told
by their sex partners that they are infected should seek care even
if they personally cannot detect any warts.
We make this recommendation because many males may have infection that can only be detected through use of a magnifying glass
and a vinegar wash.
Fifty to sixty percent of women with warts on their external genitalia
will also have cervical infection. However, only three to six percent
of women with cervical HPV infection will have external genital
warts. Hence, use of a PAP smear as a regular component of the
annual gynecologic exam has become more critical than ever. The
most common cause of a persistently abnormal PAP smear among
college women is the presence of HPV infection. Hence, women
whose PAP smears remain abnormal even after they receive treatment for other sexually transmitted diseases, will likely require further evaluation, usually by a gynecologist at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital. This is because physicians who look at PAP smears cannot readily distinguish between changes associated with HPV infection and those seen in early cervical cancer.
Treatment of external genital warts usually consists of applications
of a resin called podophyllin or liquid nitrogen. Depending on the
size of the wart, six or seven treatments, one week apart, are often
needed. Warts in the vagina or penis or on the cervix require more
specialized treatment, usually by a gynecologist or urologist. Because
the DNA from the wart virus can be incorporated into normal human
cells, HPV infections can persist and be very difficult to treat. Since
infection with one strain does not confer immunity against other
strains, one can be infected multiple times. It also appears that one
can be reinfected with the same strain even after successful treatment. As with any sexually transmitted infection, notification and
treatment of sex partners is critical.
How do you protect yourself against infection? Again, condoms
used with spermicides offer the best protection. Condoms offer a
mechanical barrier of protection while the active ingredient in spermicides (nonxyno1-9) appears capable of killing the wart virus. Use
of condoms will also decrease your risk of getting AIDS. In many
parts of the world, condoms are the primary means of contraception; among the Japanese, almost two-thirds of sexually active males
regularly use condoms. If we are to stem the • epidemic of sexually
transmitted diseases in the United States, we need to follow their lead.

Enfield shatters scoring mark
Junior reaches 1,236 points as Jays top Swarthmore
With a playoff bid on the line,
the Jays have been as unpredictable as recent developments in
the Soviet Union. Hopkins began
February trailing second-place
Widener by one game in the
MAC Southeastern Division and
facing a tough league foe, Ursinus, on the road. Coach Bill
Nelson was asked before the
game whether Hopkins was
favored to win. "Are you kidding? They beat us down here fat
Hopkins] last time!" Had Nelson
known that his leading scorer,
Andy Enfield, would be held to
eleven points, he would have
been even more concerned than
coaches usually are in such situations. The Jays came through,
however, to beat Ursinus 75-72
with a balanced offensive attack,
setting up a showdown for second
with Widener.
The Widener game began with
a strong defensive effort and a
precisely run offense. Unfortunately for Hopkins, both were
put forth by Widener, who quickly went up 10-0. A Dick Vitalelike feeling emanated throughout
the arena: Get a T.O., baby—
which Nelson did to try to help
the Jays figure out how to break
Widener's zone defense.
The results, however, were
similar to those reaped if a boxer switched from a traditional
right-handed stance to southpaw
in attempting to outpoint Mike
Tyson. By the time the half ended, the Jays were down 30-13. To
say they were struggling on offense would be quite an
understatement.

Widener came in with a simple but calculated game plan to
stop Hopkins and proceeded to
execute it to perfection. On offense, they played a slow-down
game, running the 45-second shot
clock down to 10 practically
every offensive trip. At that moment, the Widener coach would
yell "Ten!" and one of the
Widener guards would look to
drive and create. Amazingly,
Widener was able to get good
shots off, even with the shot clock
running down, and finished the
game 23-for-44 for 52 percent.
On defense they played a zone
that extended out to the threepoint circle and retracted back into the lane with astonishing
celerity. The Jays tried their usual
zone-breaking scheme by putting
Enfield and Jay Gangemi just outside the three-point circle, and
Bill Zahn on the baseline. Zahn,
however, wasn't able to connect
on his first three attempts from
that location and the Widener
guards and forwards were very
quick to jump out on Enfield
whenever he touched the ball.
This occasionally left Gangemi
open, who had hit 46 percent of
his three-pointers on the season.
But this wasn't to be his night,
unless there were recent job
openings in the bricklaying industry, as Gangemi was only able
to connect on three of twelve
treys and three of fourteen shots
overall, finishing with nine
points. The rest of the Jays'
regulars got similar results,
hoisting up 34 shots and connecting on only 12.
Widener's zone was also effective in keeping Hopkins off the

One Fan's View:

In defense of an
unappreciated art

boards, as three or four Jays were
usually on the perimeter when
shots were attempted. The basic
problem, though, was Hopkins'
lack of a third outside shooter to
break the zone. With point guard
Dave Eikenberg, whose main
jobs are to play tough defense,
run the offense, and distribute the
ball, at the top of the key,
Widener's guards were able to
leave him open for the most part
and key on Enfield. In this instance Eikenberg's unwillingness
to launch the three-pointer seemed to limit Hopkins' attack. In addition, Eikenberg had an uncharacteristic five turnovers and
only three assists. Hopkins was
also unable to get the ball inside
the zone either by inlet passes or
penetration. On several occasions
Eikenberg was able to penetrate,
but rather than breaking down the
defense he found himself surrounded by Widener players with
no one to pass the ball to.
Hopkins was able to cut the
lead to single digits after
Gangemi connected on three treys
early in the second half, but the
Jays were never able to seriously threaten Widener after that,
losing by the final score of 60-50.
Enfield was unable to get untracked, finishing with 10 points
(which led the team) on 4-9
shooting. Widener's coach implored his players to be conscious
of Enfield's location at all times.
During every timeout he could be
heard saying, "Know where Enfield is! Know where Enfield is!"

NEWS-LETTER/21

Squash tops Haverford
Travels to Yale for Howe Cup

Swimmers prepare for'IAA's

by Jerry Irvine

Leave Wednesday for championships
by Michele Royce
On Saturday, January 27, the
Hopkins swim team hosted
American University, which
featured Olympic bronze medal
winner Sergio Lopez of Spain.
The men's meet was very close,
as Hopkins' well-roundedness
shone through, with a final score
of 129 to 110 on the side of
American. Hopkins dominated
men's diving, as junior Steve
Giangrandi continued his streak
of good performances by taking
the top place on both the one and
three meter boards. Senior Mike
Dear supplemented this by taking
second place on both boards.
Other individual winners for the
Jays were senior Chris Hussin in
the 200 yard Backstroke, with a
time of 2:02.94, and freshman
Jim Quinn in the 200 Breaststroke
in 2:15.47. The Hopkins 400
Free Relay Team of seniors Mike
Costa and John Hsu,junior Steve

Muchow, and freshman Aaron
Osborne brought the race home
in 3:16.00, over 5 seconds ahead
of the second place team. And in
the 200 yard Freestyle,
American's Lopez set a new pool
record of 1:41.66.
The women also performed
well, although the final score was
not as even, with American taking 137 points to Hopkins' 97.
Sophomore Jill Christiensen earned her place on the Hopkins
women's national team by scoring 383.62 points on the 1 meter
springboard, and took first place
in the process. Sophomore
Stephanie Dengler ran away with
the race in the 1650 yard
Freestyle, finishing with a time
of 18:31.00—more than a minute
and a half ahead of American's
first swimmer. And senior cocaptain Mary Price took first
place in the 50 yard Freestyle
with a time of 26.00 seconds. The
Lady Jays' 400 Free Relay team

of Price, freshman Danielle Bird,
junior Melanie Chellman, and
senior Laura Carroll matched the
accomplishment of their male
counterpart by winning the race
with a time of 3:51.15.
The following Saturday,
February 3, Hopkins met the
team from Gettysburg College in
one of the biggest rivalries of the
year. The Hopkins men fared extremely well and finished with a
final score of 131 to Gettysburg's
72. Sophomore Lars Hondorf
was a double winner, taking the
top place in the 200 yard
Freestyle with a time of 1:48.07
and in the 500 yard Freestyle in
4:58.08. Senior co-captain Mark
Rhoads was another of the team's
several individual winners, winning the 100 yard Backstroke by
touching the wall in 56.36
seconds.
While the women were unable
to defeat the larger team from
Gettysburg College, the final

score being 116 for Gettysburg to
84 for Hopkins, there were some
extraordinary performances by
several of the Jays. Senior Mary
Price, in her last collegiate dual
meet, captured first places in both
the 50 and the 100 yard Freestyle
events, with times of 25.96 and
56.94 respectively. With the
absence of freshman Anne Hunt
due to illness, sophomore Betsy
Batchelor took control of the 100
yard Breaststroke and touched out
the second place competitor from
American by 22 one hundredths
of a second, finishing with a time
of 1:11.55. The happiest moment
of the meet came when junior cocaptain Amy Parke, who also was
in her last collegiate dual meet,
beat the qualifying standard in the
200 yard Backstroke with a time
of 2:16.85. In the spirit of true
cooperation, Gettysburg's head
coach agreed to allow Parke and
opponent Amy Shelden, who had
already qualified in the event,
to swim a 200 yard race while the
rest of the field finished at the 100
yard mark. The competition that
Shelden provided allowed Parke
to find those extra few tenths of
a second, which is what she had
previously missed the cut by. And
so one more person is headed to
Williams College in March for
Division III NCAA's.
On Wednesday, February 14,
the team leaves for St. Louis to
compete in the University
Athletic Association conference
championships at Washington
University, as both teams try to
defend their championships of
last year.

The women's squash team
defeated Haverford 7-2, avenging
a loss to the Fords earlier in the
season. The win raises the
squad's record to 2-5 and gives
the team momentum entering the
final tournament of the year, the
Howe Cup.
The squad will be competing in
the fourth division at the Howe
Cup for the second year running.
The tournament, held at Yale, is
considered the equivalent of the
national championships for collegiate squash. The team is very
young, carrying only one senior.
Also, the team aquired Frank and
Nancy Cushman as its two new
head coaches. They both expressed optimism regarding the upcoming tournament. "The team
finished third last year in the same
division," said Frank Cushman.
"We hope to do at least that well
this year, hopefully we can improve upon that standing."
The team is led by senior
Kathryn Ng, who the coaches attribute much of the teams improvement and success. Said
Frank Cushman, "She's been the
number one or two player all
year, and has led by example at
the practices and matches with
her hard work." Mr. Cushman
also stated that the entire lineup
had improved a great deal over
the course of the year and was
overall a very balanced squad.
"Anyone of the players can beat
another on a given day. That type
of inner competition is invaluable
in trying to improve and build a
strong program."
Other players making the trip
to the Howe Cup are Tara Dorr,
Karen Phillips, Natasha Dupont,
Jessica Troppe, Laura Gaffney,
Michelle Steindecker, Rosey
DaCosta,
and
Cristina
VanRiesenfelder.
The team opened the season
with a closely contested defeat at
the hands of Haverford. They

then travelled to Wesleyan in
Connecticut for a weekend tournament against Bates, Hamilton,
Wesleyan, and Cornell. Although
the competition was tough the
team came away with an uplifting
victory over Cornell. "You get
a lot out of tournaments because
the competition is so tough and
you're playing more than once a
day," stated freshman Jill Litt.
The team followed the tournament with defeats at the hands of
powerhouse Penn and Franklin &
Marshall. The last match against
Haverford was a much needed
victory against a tough Haverford
team. Said sophomore Rosy
DaCosta, "The last Haverford
match showed how much we've
improved over the course of the
season."
The team has worked hard
throughout the season, which
began in November, but have had
difficulty due to the tough competition and lack of experience.
Said sophomore Rosy DaCosta,
"Playing a nationally ranked
team like Franklin & Marshall
can be demoralizing, but at the
same time it is a very valuable
learning experience to play
against such good competition."
Many of Hopkins opponents
this year have players who have
been playing squash for many
years. In addition, most of the op-posing schools have several
juniors and seniors, in stark contrast to the Hopkins squad which
besides being comprised mostly
of freshmen and sophomores also
carries many newcomers to the
game of squash. Coach Frank
Cushman sees this youth movement as a positive aspect of the
team. "The hard work and good
attitude the team has carried with
them all year will definetly pay
off in the years to come. The fact
that the players are so young
makes me very positive about the
trend the team is taking for the
future."

Praise for the pencil pushers
A writer on the most-read section
JOSH, from 20
Exceptional sportswriting exists, and deserves as much credit
as exceptional writing in any
other form of journalism. In
America today, where more people read the sports section than
read the first section, the value of
talented sportswriters cannot be
understated.
Sports are integral to American

culture. As Jacques Barzun wrote
in "God's Country and Mine,"
"Whoever wants to know the
heart and mind of America had
better learn baseball." The same
could be said of football or
basketball. America is a country
full of athletes and fans, and the
sportswriter is the interpreter of
the games.
Red Smith said his "goal was
to entertain . . . and capture the

grace and drama and beauty and
humor." A sportswriter's role is
not to place athletes on Mount
Olympus and offer sacrifices nor
to write cliche-ridden babble. His
role is to entertain and educate,
as any journalist should, for
sportswriting is only as limited as
a sportswriter's ability.

February 9, 1990

by Alex Varon

The manufacture of fake IDs has led to the arrests of three Hopkins
students.

Three Hopkins students were
arrested last Tuesday, January
30, for allegedly producing false
driver's licenses. They have been
charged with possession of fictional driver's licenses and
possession of fraudulent or
altered driver's licenses.
It is believed that the three
students, juniors Mark Maneche
and Douglas Schmidt and senior
Jon Driscoll, had been providing
the licenses for six to nine
months. During this time, it is
supposed that anywhere from 15
to 35 false Ohio State driver's
licenses were sold for $40 each.

Many of the licenses have been
recovered.
All three students declined to
comment.
The scheme was an inventive
one. Purchasers of the fake
licenses would pose behind a
large cardboard poster, which
essentially was a blown-up copy
of an Ohio state driver's license.
Information would be tacked onto the board, and a picture of the
whole would be taken. After processing, the licenses were cut out
and laminated.
The police investigation was initiated Tuesday morning when a
film-processing firm contacted
police regarding an attempt to

produce false Ohio driver's
licenses. One roll of film was
recovered.
Dean of Students Susan
Boswell is currently reviewing
the case and may call a
disciplinary hearing for the
students involved in the scheme.
"We're doing what we would
do with any other non-academic
violation," said Boswell. "We
know that many students use fake
ID's to obtain alcohol, but this is
the first case we've had with such
a scheme."
If found guilty, the students
may face possible expulsion.

by Bradley Cohen
"Being assertive is a right
everyone has," asserted Dean of
Students Susan Boswell, who
delivered this week's Learn at
Lunch lecture. The lecture entitled "Tell it Like it Is!" is part
of an ongoing series of lunchtime
lectures designed to help the
Hopkins community deal with
problems and learn self-help
techniques.
Boswell identified three types
of behavior: non-assertive, aggressive, and assertive. Since
behavior is often a reflection of
how one is feeling, it is important to understand what type of
behavior one is presenting and

how to change it.
Non-assertive behavior was
defined by Dean Boswell as
"allowing one's personal rights
to be violated by another's." The
primary motive of non-assertive
behavior is to avoid conflict or
confrontation. This is reflected in
a person's body language. For instance, speaking very quietly or
mumbling, using a defensive
posture, or having a facial expression not congruent with what is
being said are all displays of nonassertive behavior.
Typical behavior of a nonassertive person would include
keeping feelings internalized or

Dreams discussed at Wellness
by Chris VandeKieft
"I think as a culture we probably pay less attention to dreams
than earlier cultures," said
Simone Campbell-Scott last
Tuesday during "Dreams: Symbols in the Night," the Wellness
program's first 1990 Learn at
Lunch Series lecture.
Campbell-Scott began with a
"quick and dirty" definition of
dreams, stating that "the ego is
our conscious self . . . what we
know we know . . . The I, the
subjective self." The unconscious
"is most evident to us in two
places—in dreams and in fantasies." These basic notions of
Swiss psychologist Jung and
Austrian psychoanalyst Sigmund
Freud are "subject to a lot of
debate," she said. "Dreams are
metaphorical statements," she
continued, transmitted in "symbolic and metaphoric language."
A brief history of dreams
followed, and Campbell-Scott
remarked that although dreams
figured prominently in the Old

and New Testaments and in many
past societies, Americans are frequently skeptical about them.
"You shouldn't be daydreaming" is a common sentiment here,
she said.
But dream study can be
beneficial, she stated, paraphrasing Jungian analyst James Hall's
view that "by paying attention to
our dreams we can enlarge our
consciousness" and "become
aware of issues that have driven
us . . . as we become more aware
of our unconscious, we become
more aware of choices." Jung,
she said, held that "aspects of
ourselves that we are unaware of
are in our unconsciousness and
manifest themselves in dreams."
She added that dreams might contain elements of a dreamer's
individuation, the process
whereby one develops a sense of
identity.
A practical method to study
dreams, Campbell-Scott said, is
to pay close attention to, and to
question extensively the details of
the dream. "Put a notebook by

your bed to write it down," she
said of a hypothetical dream, and
"tell yourself before you sleep to
do it . . . once you have the
dream itself, what is the setting?"
Also important is "the dream ego
. . . the I in the dream . . . the
part that is most like your conscious ego." One should
scrutinize, she continued, the
issues, conflicts, and people surrounding the dream ego.
She stressed that other objects,
such as a house, a method of
transportation, or animals in the
dream could also be important.
"All of those tell you something
about yourself." One should Ask
"what are the feelings [you]
associate with it" and "what does
it mean to [you]?"
Also, one could "ask what are
[your] associations in the dream
to what happened in the day," or
determine "your own association
to each element of the dream."
Campbell-Scott said that some
dreams feature characters from a
dreamer's past, a character the
scarcely
might
dreamer

remember. This person, of the
same sex as the dreamer, was
called a "shadow figure" by
Jung. The figure might represent
"a rejected part of yourself' and
can be "a way of getting in touch
with some rejected aspect of
yourself."
One might talk to a shadow
figure, or another mysterious
dream character, to learn more
about it, Campbell-Scott noted.
The dreamer could try, during the
dream, "asking the question and
then letting the answer be
whatever it is . . . if it gets scary
. . . then stop it. You don't have
to keep going. You are not under
a very powerful spell."
Though some forget their
dreams, Campbell-Scott said
'
"you can discipline yourself"
through practice and effort to
enhance dream retention.
One "can learn a great deal inside and out of therapy," by
studying dreams, she said. "I
think it enriches our lives."

Dean Boswell identified was aggressive behavior. Aggressive
behavior is defined as behavior
used by an individual to achieve
something which denies others

their personal rights. Aggressive
behavior includes a tone of voice
which may be loud or cold, a stiff

Sometimes people who are inwardly insecure use aggression to
divert attention from themselves.
Other explanations for aggressive
behavior include childhood experiences, previous success or a
fear of loss of power. Aggressive
behavior is expressed verbally
through the use of "loaded"
words, which are words that can
have multiple meanings. It can
also be displayed through the use

OXFORD
Several colleges of Oxford University have invited The
Washington International Studies Council to recommend
qualified students to study for one year or for one or two
terms. Lower Junior status is required. and graduate study
is available. Students are directly enrolled in their colleges
and receive transcripts from their Oxford college; this is NOT
a program conducted by a U.S. College in Oxford. 3.2
minimum index in major required.
An alternative program which is sponsored by a U.S.
University is available for students with minimum indexes of
2.7. Students will have social and athletic rights in an Oxford
college and the fees are substantially less.

Government and Journalism courses are taught by seniorlevel government officials, who are also scholars, and by
experienced journalists. Similar opportunities in public
policy internships are offered (with academic credit) in
London (Fall, Spring and Summer).

The Punchline
by Christopher T. McColl
The punchline is this: the
postman cometh . . .
Today I pull yet another letter
from the bulging bag of fan mail
that I receive every week from
you readers at home. This week's
postal tidbit comes from Nelson
Finefare, an imaginary Biology
major, who asks:
"Dear Chris: Every week you
receive a bulging bag of fan mail
from your readers at home, but
you never respond to any of it in
your column because you're too
busy using it to misrepresent your
friends. Wouldn't it be more efficient to just write us back, via
the good old U.S. Postal
Service?"
The fact of the matter is that
I'm afraid to use the mail ysstem.
My explanation begins with two
elements: my obsessivecompulsive behavior, and the
toaster oven that my brother
bought me last year for Christmas
(which I still haven't opened).
Perhaps this explanation will be
of use to those of you who, for
whatever reason, don't get
around to writing people you
know.
I have a friend who lives in
Florida with a toaster oven just
like the one I just mentioned. We
are very close, at least as close
as two people who see each other
at most one week out of each year
can be.
I submit (and I don't think my
editors will disagree with me
here) that were I to begin writing
to her, my letters would be
similarly long-winded. But it
would take too long for me to
finish each letter, and the guilt
would build up, along with an
obsessive-compulsive urge to
end letter after letter. So,I would
'probably end up sending a page
of a letter every day.
I think it's safe to assume that
anyone would get annoyed trying
to read a letter a page at a time,
so she would collect my letters in
a brown bag in her kitchen, promising herself that she'd open
them all up one day and read
them, while each night she'd just
rationalize a different reason as

to why she hadn't opened them.
One night she'll say it's
because she's in a hurry to get to
aerobics class. This will be the
class, of course, in which she
meets that tall, handsome stranger
wearing Eau-de-recent-graduateof-Penn-business-school-who'sin-Florida-to-make-a-killing-inthe-condo-game, and the two will
walk along the beach and talk into
the wee hours. He will try
nothing more daring than a goodnight kiss, because he's really
very sensitive, and it just doesn't
feel right, besides he doesn't want
to do anything that she doesn't.
She insists that she's got to go
because she's got to get up early
for work and oh my God it's
already 3:30.
While Rourke writes his
number on the back of the letter she got from me that day, she
explains that she was going to
write to me the other day, but she
had to get her toaster oven
repaired. Of course, she got there
just as the place was closing, so
they couldn't fix it anyway. The
sensitive Rourke will know exactly how she feels, because he's
been having trouble with the
phone company.
The next morning, she'll hurriedly grab her toast on her way
out, knocking the toaster oven off
the counter and into the bag filled with my letters, yanking the
plug out of the wall as it fall, but
she'll be so late that she won't
have time to fix it. She'll get to
it later. Anyway, it's unplugged.
But while she's gone, the
heating elements inside the
machine, which are, of course,
still glowing, will come in contact with one of my letters, and
start it smouldering, eventually
igniting the whole bag and
destroying all of my work.
At this point, however, she's at
work smiling goofily, daydreaming about Rourke and playing
with the envelope with his phone
number. Her boss walks past,
startling her, and she rips open
the letter as though it's some imSee PUNCHLINE, 5

Here a condom. .
While flipping through the pages of the News-Letter to
find the crossword puzzle, some of you were probably surprised to find a condom inserted within its pages. The
papers delivered to the Homewood campus this week contain condoms, not as some stunt done for shock value or
a good laugh, but rather to stress the importance of education and responsibility in practicing safe sex.
Two years ago, when the News-Letter first delivered
condoms with its Valentine's Day issue, most Americans
could not say the word "condom" in mixed company
without people raising their eyebrows or laughing nervously. Since then, education has been instrumental in not only lowering the condom's mystery and embarrassing
reputation, but also in teaching people about
the benefits of using condoms.
The condom is not just a means of contraception. Using a condom correctly can protect both you and your partner from the spread of many sexually transmitted diseases.
The Health Center suggests the following simple steps to
safe sex with a condom: 1) Ensure before use that the condom's package is sealed, and that it has been stored in a
cool, dry place. If you are unsure of how long it's been
sulking around your apartment, don't use it. 2) While putting on the condom (which can be an intimate part of

•

foreplay and not just an embarrassing pause in the middle
of things), make sure there is space in the tip to act as a
reservoir and then roll it all the way on to the penis. 3)
Use lubricants that are water-soluble and contain a spermicide such as Nonoxyl 9. 4) After climax, remove the
erect penis before it relaxes in the vagina. Hold the condom at its base and be careful not to tear it as you slowly
withdraw. 5) Another important step in using a condom
is discussing the decision to use one with your partner.
Opening the channels of communication can improve an
already intimate relationship. It is important to remember
that just because a man wears the condom, the choices and
responsibilies involved are not his alone, but those of his
partner as well.
In providing you with condoms, the News-Letter is not
inviting you to drape them from trees, inflate them in class,
or scatter them all over Gilman. What we do hope is that
you will deal with them responsibly, even if this means
throwing them, unopened, into the nearest trash bin.
Additional information on condoms and safe sex is
available at the Health Center. Condoms are available there
for a dollar a dozen. The Union Desk also has a wide selection, in a variety of shapes, colors and styles, available
for your perusal.

The right to write
It has been suggested that a Hopkins publication might
be in jeopardy of losing its funding, as well as SAC
recognition, were it to publish something which the majority of the SAC board found distasteful or inappropriate.
Such an intrusive move on the part of the SAC would not
be a good idea.
When editors are presented with material which may be
offensive to certain groups or individuals on campus, they
must be allowed to make the decision as to whether or not
the material is fit for publication. To mandate "tolerance,"
by setting strict guidelines as to what the SAC or the
University finds offensive, is to render such a decision
meaningless. As it has been said before, one cannot
legislate morality.
Student government, or the University administration,
must be clearly separated from student publications. For
a publication to be meaningful, its editors must have a certain level of responsibility for its contents. An editor must
have the right and responsibility to edit staff work (letters

to the editor are another issue). If a reader doesn't like
a certain journal's bias or choice of material, he or she
should be able to choose another or even begin his or her
own publication, with the SAC's blessing and funding.
Proliferating campus publications would yield a wider
range of ideas and forums, the aggregate result being a
better representation of campus awareness through a variety of editorial boards. The SAC, as an arm of the student
government, must stay out of this entire process, aside
from acting as a facilitator. If the SAC,or the Administration, were to set artificial publication content guidelines,
they might well be guilty of censorship.
We suggest that the SAC invest in a desktop publishing
system, complete with a set of terminals, software and a
laser printer,which would be available to any group which
wanted to publish. The consequential growth in the campus press would both invigorate campus intellectual life,
and remove the pressure from existing publications to be
all things to all people.

Letters
Homewood II
Homewood I
The following letter was
distributed to the Homewood
community this past week.

To All Members of the
Homewood Community:
The cartoon published in the
Hopkins Spectator, Volume 2,
Issue Number 3, is of concern.
It is this sort of publication that
helps create and promote an environment accepting sexism. In
addition, it promoted an irresponsible attitude towards the consumption of alcohol. It is in opposition to the mission of an institute of higher learning.
As the Deans of Homewood
Schools, we are committed to improving the climate at Homewood
for all members of the Community. We applaud the Student Activities Commission for taking action and scheduling a hearing and
feel confident that appropriate action will be taken.
It is our goal to establish an environment that is sensitive to the
needs of inidividuals within the
community and fosters tolerance
and the pursuit of knowledge. We
urge all members of the
Homewood Community to support and assist us in creating an
environment that is conducive to
this goal.

To the Editors:
In response to a letter received by "all members of the
Homewood Community" I question the commitment our university hierarchy has towards "improving the climate at
Homewood." Those who signed
the letter seemed to feel that an
improvement in our community
should come through censorship
of student publications. It has
long been tradition that universities allow students to use their
own discretion in deciding what
is proper for print and what is inappropriate. If the students feel
that what they are reading is offensive, they should react responsibly and with maturity, not by
running to the nearest university
official. It is absolutely inconceivable that the proper way
to respond is through censorship.
On the masthead of"The Johns
Hopkins News-Letter "it says:
"Student Publication Since
1897." I beg the Jesse Helmses,
the Joseph McCartheys, and the
fascists of the university administration, to allow the students
to continue free publication, and
to keep the ninety-three year old
student publication alive and
uncensored.
Avi Fisher
Andrew B. Donnalley
Yu-Chie Lin

Editors note:
The News-Letter would like to
clarify the circumstances surrounding the showing of James
Rosen 's last "With Eyes Closed"
to the Black Student Union. We
were not involved. Mr. Rosen
gave a copy ofthe cartoon, which
we had declined to publish, to the
Spectator. The Spectator then
showed it to the Black Student

Union. All questions as to the
selective showing of the cartoon
in question should be directed
either to Mr. Rosen, or to the
Spectator, as they are the parties
whose actions precipitated last
week's letters to the editorfrom
those present at the BSU meeting.

To the Editors:
If you're a regular reader of the
Johns Hopkins News-Letter,
what should you reasonably have
concluded from your perusal of
the February 2 edition's editorial
page? You might have concluded that James Rosen had drawn
some kind of "racist...ignorant'
cartoon about the Snack Bar staff
here at Hopkins.
If you read all five of the letters
that conspired to generate this
conclusion, you may then consider yourself acquainted with a
standard hypocrisy and disdain
for you, the reader, that you probably will never again encounter
with printed material.
Letters to the editor are usually persuasive efforts, and these
were no different save for one
aspect. You were told that you
would certainly agree with these
people if you were allowed to see
Rosen's drawing, but that you
should not see the strip in the first
place, because it might upset you.
These were thus the first letters
to the editor I've ever read whose
authors sought to deny you the information that would most win
you to their sides.
You were also led to believe
that the undeniability of this conclusion, that I draw racist cartoons, stems from the diversity of
background in those who felt
equipped to comment on it. Five
people who somehow had more
right than you to see this cartoon...as well as five attendants
of the same meeting of a single
student group, which looks about

as impartial as five Klansmen
testifying together.
It would seem to me, then, that
any such persuasive efforts would
be consigned to failure ifjust one
person, after finishing the fifth
letter, thought to him or herself:
"Well, what did the comic strip
actually SAY?" What could these
letter writers respond to you—
"Uh, trust us on this one, really." It's like asking a jury to
believe that a photograph shows
the murder in action, without
showing the jury the photograph.
The reason for not printing the
cartoon is, simply, that my
detractors are afraid of what you
might do if you saw this cartoon.
Carlos Pezua, who complained
about two comic strips in one
week, claimed that my drawing
would prompt from you "a tirade
of racial outbursts." Throughout
this sorry episode, I have never
wavered in my trust of your ability to read and think for
yourselves, like some have, nor
have I ever believed, as some,
that a cartoon would lead you to
violent behavior.
Personally I find the idea of
trying to debate the merits of a
concealed picture kind of...insipid...and so I will not demean
you, as some have, by asking you
to believe anything at all about the
strip until you've seen it for
yourself.
As for my detractors' logic,
that is there for all to see. Mr.
Pezua wrote, "The problem with
this comic strip is that it harshly
adresses a sensitive issue." I
would characterize Do The Right
Thing in the same way.
George Lerner told you I
bordered n Fascism while asking
you to convict me on unseen
evidence—much like a show trial
in a...Fascist...country. "Look,
we got five people to say it!" Mr.
Lerner also lamented to you the

Speaker's Comer

Rebecca Garron
It is about time that the Hopkins
Community—male, female,
Black, White, Gentile or Jew,
faculty or student—recognized
the pervasive institutionalization
of sexism, racism, and exclusivism. It is also time for
special interests groups to
reevaluate their criticisms of Mr.
Podurgiel's cartoon, which I
would like to defend from
impassioned
misdirected,
criticism.
I am a member, in no prioritized order, of the female, white,
and Jewish Hopkins communities, and am painfully aware
of the prejudices directed at the
membership of at least two of
these. I am also aware that
"special interest" groups, being
human, are fallible, and, when
victimized, can rashly critize
without fully understanding the
complexities of an issue.
Mr. Podurgiel's cartoon,
though lacking intellectual skill
(i.e. it is impossible to decipher
his postion), is not necessarily
sexist. His cartoon rendered,
through a not-so-comic comic
medium, a conversation to which
every male and female at Hopkins
has been subjected; that is the
belief first, that women at
Hopkins are physically unattractive, and second, the real sexism,
that in fact the only way in which
to acknowledge women is as sexual entities. (It might be interesting to note that the cartoon
further implies that Hopkins men
are incapable of any kind of relationship sans alchohol). His cartoon does not necessarily agree
with those beliefs, nor does it
necessarily suggest that Mr.
Podurgiel espouses those beliefs.
The cartoon is perhaps a means
by which to publicize the existence of those beliefs, and obviously, it did so successfully.
This is an important distinction.
I can not speak for Mr.
Poduirgal's sensibilities; I can
only hope to draw attention to the

cartoon so that we can all ask
what it means and in what ways
it is productive to the Hopkins
community. I do hold Mr.
Podurgiel responsible for his
words. Having explicitly invited
criticism, it is now his obligation
to respond to those criticisms.
Mr. Podurgiel?
Both the victimized and the victimizers are members of the
Hopkins community. We all have
responsibilities to that community, and there are productive ways
of confronting divisive issues.
1. Censorship is not the
answer. Women's groups in particular have called for the suppression of sexist material. Censorship only creates a violently
pressurized silence beneath which
breeds prejudice and misconceptions, both of which, given time,
will explode in our faces. A more
productive way of confronting
and eradicating prejudice is to
publicly engage those who nurture such prejudice. Either
boycott those publications which
encourage ignorance or use those
publications as a vehicle of
debate. The responsibility is not
to denounce, but to inform.
2. Obviously, it is not only the
victimized who are responsible
for eradicating the ignorance
underlying
destructive
misconceptions. Publications, the
administration, and special interest groups alike are responsible for providing a forum in
which all can engage in healthy
discourse. The most blameworthy in this entire situation is not
Mr. Podurgiel, nor individual
sexists (though they contribute to
the problem), nor any one special
interest group. It is The Spectator, a publication which does
not even pretend to have an agenda and which chooses to attack
the personal qualities of individuals, rather than discuss
issues in any depth. If asked. I am
both happy and prepared to provide examples of The Spectator's

3. No group on campus is solely responsible to itself; women's

Hopkins; let's examine our own

tion: equating—completely
unjustly—the violent pornography of the TEP publication
with the first-offence, and certainly tame-by-comparison,
Hopkins Spectator.
To be fair, Mr. Ellis may not
have reckoned that the connection
would so obviously be made. The
editors fo the News-Letter have
no such excuse for the labeling of
the Spectator as "campus'
equivalent of the Dartmouth
Review." This is a wholly unjust
comparison. The Spectator has
yet to break any University rules;
the Review has yet to adhere to
any, many might say.
Above all, the Spectator has yet
to acquire—no thanks to the NL, mind you—the same notoriety for inaccuracy and irresponsibility as the Review has.
When I spoke to the editor
who'd written the piece, I was
told that all that was meant was
that the Spectator is funded by the
same organization that funds the
Review. This is not entirely true:
the Review receives no funding
from the organization, though it
is a member of the same umbrella
group, the Collegiate Network.
But then so are 52 other campus
publications. Are they all to be
tarred with the same brush?
Moreover, if it truly was simply
the funding question that the
editors meant to draw attention
to, I feel sure that slightly less
loaded phraseology would have
been employed.
To the editors of the NewsLetter: if you want to be sanctimonious about editorial responsibility, you might just want to
start at home.
As for everyone else, while I
cannot say that we Spectator staff
relish being harangued in the corridor, we acknowledge your right
to do it. Do you recognize the
Spectator's right to publish
material that breaks no federal
laws nor SAC rules? Think about
it.

BERMUDA
COLLEGE WEEKS
Right from the start,
the pleasures are nonstop.
Your holiday begins with a day-long
Barbecue Bash at beautiful Elbow
Beach: dancing, feasting and tanning
on soft, pink, sun-splashed sands.
The fun continues with spectacular
beach parties featuring Bermuda's top
rock, steel and calypso bands. Daily
lunches. A limbo festival. An outrageous Party Cruise to magnificent Great
Sound. Plus golf, tennis and rugby
tournaments—and a "Murder, Mystery
and Mayhem" contest that'll have you
super-sleuthing. All compliments of
Bermuda's Department of Tourism.
Add to that all the things that make
Bermuda, Bermuda. British ambiance.
Colourful pubs. Whirring about on a
moped. Treasure-hunting in our shops.
And the special feeling of being separated from everywhere and everything
by 600 miles Of sea.
This spring, get your R&R on a very
special island. Contact your Campus
Travel Representative.or Travel Agent
for Bermuda College Week details.

Certainly some publishing

differs from what I consider to
be, just as both our views differ
from everyone else's. Thus,
blindly to ascribe to the thoushalt-not-offend-anyone school of
thought is a disastrous policy.
And one invariably administered
with bias.
But the more important question is that of what such policies
do to one's constitutional rights.
Both the University of Michigan
at Ann Arbor and Tufts University, to name two examples
among many, recently enacted
anti-harassment policies that
made it a punishable offense to
engage in conduct that
"stigmatizes or victimizes"
groups or individuals. What constituted stigmatization was not
codified. The ACLU took U.
Michigan to court for violating
the First Amendment. And won.
The university has had to
withdraw the the rules.
Presumably in anticipation of
similar treatment, Tufts has
voluntarily rescinded its policy.
Chalk one up to Justice.
And while the comparison of
JHU with other campuses may
strike the reader as somewhat
over-the-top, I would like to end
by noting that I am certainly not
the only one guilty of drawing unjust parallels. Chad Ellis in his article smoothly glides from excoriating the Spectator to denouncing the "legendary TEP fraternity newsletter." The reader is

Quite apart from the fact that
the supposed "2x +1 " scandal
is no business of the News-Letter
whatsoever, last week's staff
editorial piece was no more and
no less than a blatant bit of selfserving advertising by the
editorial team.
The subtlety with which the
homily on the Spectator's current
troubles was transformed into a
combination of mea culpa for past.
News-Letter tolerance for the
alleged intolerance on the part of
its staff members, of course—
caught me off-guard at first. Then
came the promise of future
squeaky-cleanliness, for "sexism
and racism have no place on our
campus, or in the News-Letter."
Sorry, but no. Much as we all
may dislike it, there is a place on
this campus for anything that is
legal—and on my last reading of
a statute book, publishing
distasteful cartoons was not a
misdemeanor. Let alone the
felony it is being made out to be.
I, as the editor at the time of
the Spectator, had no grounds for
disallowing the "2x +1" cartoon.
It was not obscene, pornographic
or libelous, the only grounds on
which
contributions
are
automatically rejected. Further,
seeing as how this university as
yet has no policy of dictating what
sort of things may be published,
no SAC rules have been broken.
In a recent letter to everyone on
campus, the administration,
perhaps more with an air of selfrighteousness than of detachment,
applauded the SAC for contemplating action against the
Spectator: I can only repeat, we
have broken none of your rules.
It was all a matter of my
discretion.
I thought the cartoon was just
acceptable. Readers may
disagree, but the point is that the
issue is a value call. And despite
the ire that is currently being
served up to the Spectator, it
seems to me that what we have
is not a "campus of angry women
and men" (N-L "Spectator II"
letter) but, rather, a campus
predominantly full of people

To the Editors:
Like a lot of people around
here, I've been having some
memory problems as of late. In
last week's News-Letter there
were six letters referring to a
James Rosen cartoon which I
don't remember seeing published. It turned out that my memory
hadn't failed me—the cartoon had
been suppressed and five of the
letters were messages of congratulation to the editors for a job
well done. It turned out that the
five letter writers saw the cartoon
in a meeting of the Black Student
Union. It also turned out that the
News-Letter has a circulation of
six-thousand. After some simple
subtraction I realized that not too
many people are going to be able
to contextualize the remarks of
Rosens's critics, cogent though
they may be.
Then my memory began working overtime, and I recalled an
unpleasant incident this summer,
which was reported in the
newspapers and on television, so
many News-Letter readers might
recall it as well. Robert Mapplethorpe, a photographer of
some renown and now deceased,
was to have his work exhibited at
the Concoran Gallery in
Washington D.C. The exhibit

was to be sponsored by the National Endowment for the Arts,
until Senator Jesse Helms protested due to the homoerotic
nature of some of the
photographs. NEA funding was
revoked and the exhibit was moved to a smaller gallery amid controversy and debate. Newspaper
and television standards are such
that none of the photographs in
question could appear for the
public on whose behalf,
presumably, the debate began.
Many students who are pleased to
see James Rosen's cartoon
railroaded out of existence were
probably outraged at the attempt
to supress Mapplethorpe's work.
Many of the arguments against
the publicaton of the cartoon,
specifically those forwarded by
George Lerner, Makeba Lindsay,
and Craig Freeman mirror those
of Senator Helms in opposition to
the Mapplethorpe exhibit.
It is arrogant of the News-Letter
editors to presume to moderate a
debate which their own restrictive
editorial policies have considered
moot. (It is perhaps this same arrogance which compelled the
News-Letter. to run an editorial
about its editorial policies over
the editorial on our new president.) If this debate is to continue
the cartoon must be published.
Newspapers, like government,
serve a public need. When they
try to dictate public need to serve
themselves their function
deteriorates into self-abuse.

Finally, is it sexist to think a
woman homely? Or must one's
concept of beauty also be radically democratic making all
beautiful as to not offend anyone?

David Cohen

To the Editors:
I must take issue with some of
the opinions raised in last week's
issue of the News-Letter. George
Lerner says that "the idea
borders on Fascism" that James
Rosen should be allowed to print
whatever he wants. Although
common sense should be sufficient to discover the moronic
reasoning behind such a conclusion, maybe a more complete
criticism is required. Fascism
properly defined is a form of
government that unites business
and state leadership with a
belligerent nationalism. The most
"successful" form of fascism is
totalitarianism which is a society
based on extreme unity and
authoritarianism, usually some
form of dictatorship. Totalitarian
regimes make much use of propaganda, a word which originates
from the Catholic counterreformation and the Holy Office
for the Propagation of the Faith.
Censorship is an authoritarian
concept as is coercive propagation of faith (whatever that faith
may be—for example religion and
radical democracy.)

To the Editors:
McCarthyist-type
demagoguery in the name of
wiping out sexism, racism, antisemitism and homophobism is a
growing problem at Hopkins.
The News-Letter's decision to
join with the Women's Center in
supporting the censorship of the
"2x +1" strip is particularly
disturbing.
I didn't expect anything more
from the Women's Center.
Feminists at Hopkins have traditionally thrived on finding
something with sexual overtones
and changing it into the most
horrible piece ever written. This
is precisely the strategy used by
Joe McCarthy in his battle against
Communism. In the past, The
Women's Center has even
resorted to opening other people's
mail, as Mr. Ellis so eloquently
points out. This is a federal offense, but nothing new to Joe
McCarthy and his disciples.
The Women's Center should
also keep in mind that they don't
speak for all the women at J.H.U.
Most females I have talked with
have no problem with the comic
strip; some even found it funny.
As for the News-Letter's reaction, I am stunned. McCarthyistlike fringe groups will always
exist, but it is only when
newspapers and other media
outlets join the witch hunt that
things start getting dangerous. In
last week's editorial, the NewsLetter asserts "sexism and racism
have no place on our campus."
Who judges what is sexist or
racist and what is not? The NewsLetter! In the 2x +1 controversy,
the News-Letter views sexism in
very encompassing terms. Where
does the News-Letter draw the
line? Does every movie shown on
campus have to be screened to
make sure no scene is derogatory
to some group? I hope it never
comes to this, but the News-Letter
is on a dangerous road. McCarthy defined liberals, civil libertarians and many others who
disagreed with him as Communists. Is everyone who annoys
the radical feminists doomed to
be labeled as sexist?
When the News-Letter preaches
about "promoting tolerance on
campus," they should keep in
mind that censorship of free
speech is antithetical to tolerance.
It is in this spirit that I encourage
anyone who disagrees with the
basic tenents of this article to respond in next week's News-Letter.
You see, everyone is entitled to
their own opinion: even
McCarthy ists
Dan Abrams

Each of us on the Spectator
editorial board fully abhor the atthe
in
depicted
titude
cartoon. The attitude is sexist,
utterly
derrogatory, and
repulsive. Nevertheless, the attitude does exist on the Hopkins
campus. One can easily find
many instances of male Hopkins
students talking in such a manner.
Many readers seem to have
forgotten that this is an editorial
cartoon, and as such, it is not
meant to endorse this attitude.
Any cartoon, whether it be found
on the editorial page of a
newspaper or in the comic section, attempts to take a slice of
life and present it under a
microscope for all to see. The
"2x +I" cartoon does exactly
this, for it forces us all to confront
sexism on campus.
The cartoon has, therefore,
succeeded in its task. It has forced us all—both males and
females—to reevaluate our attitudes toward the opposite sex.
It has stimulated discussion of
sexism; before the cartoon was
published, there was very little,
if any, serious discussion of this
important issue. Open discussion
of prejudices is always more
fruitful than the suppression and
failure to acknowledge such attitudes. As long as discussion is
occurring, we are all kept aware
of the problem of sexist attitudes,
and we can do something to
change them.
Before such discussion occurs,
we should all become responsible readers and should not
misconstrue the cartoonist's intent. As we said before, this was
a cartoon. The two males
depicted in it were not intended
to be people whom we should
respect. Instead, they looked silly and repulsing. We all became
conscious of the sexist attitudes
that do exist on campus. As Carl
Pezua wrote in a letter last week,
"This comic strip made me

think—really think—about the attitudes and sensitivities of
Hopkins students." In my opinion, the cartoon fully served its
purpose.
Sandeep Kishan
Layout Editor
The Spectator

APL
To the Editors:
I am writing in regard to the article entitled "APL Tests
Missiles" by Mr. Stephen
Mizrach in your issue of
February 2. I do not wish to
[dispute] any of the points which
Mr. Mizrach makes in his article,
but I do dispute the objectivity of
his coverage.
It appears from the text of his
article that Mr. Mizrach relied
exclusively on testimony from
professional peace activists (or at
least people willing to be described as peace activists). Now, it
should be obvious that any peace
activist will oppose nuclear
testing in any form. At the very
least, Mr. Mizrach could have included a statement by someone
from A.P.L.(or, for that matter,
the Navy) as to the role of Trident II in protecting America's
security interests in what he quite
correctly describes as a time
when "Soviet military response
is so unpredictable."
There is no doubt that nuclear
weapons, in and of themselves,
are horrible and disturbing things.
But they are also a component of
America's national defense which
has negated the threat of world
war for over forty years. Only
after journalists such as Steve
Mizrach begin to write more
balanced articles can the general
readership (of this paper or any
other) become cognizant of the
benefits as well as the costs of our
nation's nuclear capabilities.

Letters Policy

Council
To the Editors:
As president of the Student
Council I would like to inform
everyone of two very important
changes to the regular functions
of the Council. First, our weekly meetings for commitee
business and open discussions
will be held in the Shriver Hall
Board Room every Wednesday
evening at 1:00 p.m. unless
otherwise posted. This is one
hour earlier than before and as
usual the meetings are open to all
students.
Second, the Student Council
office has been moved to the first
floor of Levering Hall adjacent to
the StudeTit Activities Office. For
those of you who are't familiar
with the location, just make a left
at the Great Hall and it will be
through the first door on your
right. Student Council members
have office hours from 9:00 a.m.
to 5:00 p.m. if you have any concerns you would like to address.
The office is also the place for all
elected and student appointed
positions, such as Orientation,
M.S.E. Symposium, and Spring
Fair chairs, and Student Council
positions. The phone number in
the office is 338-8203 if there are
any questions and an answering
machine is in effect after hours. I
I hope that everyone at some
point in their time here at
Hopkins will take the opportunity to voice an opinion or concern
on an aspect of student life they
feel needs to be improved. The
Student Council is just one
mechanism for that purpose, and
in order for it to be effective we
need as much participation and
diversity as is possible. To that
effect, no one should feel excluded and we will attempt to remain
a visible body for students in the
time to come.
Lou Giangiulio

James L. T. Knighton
President,
The Johns Hopkins
College Republicans

The News-Letter welcomes letters to the editors. Letters must
be typed, double spaced, and include the author's name and
telephone for verification purposes. The News-Letter reserves
the right to edit for condensation.
Letters must be delivered to the
Gatehouse by Tuesday at 5 p.m.
for inclusion in that Friday's
paper. Once a letter is delivered
it becomes the property of the
News-Letter. Letters must be
signed by at least one person and
no more than two persons. Letters credited only to organizations
will not be printed. Due to the
volume of letters received and not
all can be printed, we reserve the
right to limit the number of letters printed in a given issue.

Arts
MOVIES

THE A TER

Mazursky's
Outstanding,
Bittersweet
'Enemies'

Theatre Lab
Alternately
Pleasing and
Unpolished

by Mark Friedman

by Christopher T. McColl

A tangible bittersweetness coats every frame of
Paul Mazursky's exceptional "Enemies, A Love
Story." Although the film can be quickly described as the adventures of a man who is married to
three women, some far more grueling machinations are at work here. Herman Broder and his
wives are Holocaust survivors, part of a select few
with permanent, unthinkable stains on their
memories.
Based on an Isaac Bashevis Singer novel,
"Enemies" is such a compelling tale that one
almost misses its larger, more insidious themes.
Herman (Ron Silver) is a struggling writer who
survived the Nazi scourge through the aid of Yadwiga (Margaret Sophie Stein), a Polish peasant
girl who sequestered him in her hayloft during the
war. Married out of Herman's sense of obligation, they now live together on Coney Island,
although he continues to see camp survivor Masha
(Lena Olin) on the side.
Herman's marital responsibilities are laced with
guilt: when he's about to forget Yadwiga entirely, he hears the barking dogs of the German occupation, and feels the blows that
Yadwiga withstood to preserve their secret. Yadwiga'a link to Herman is both maternal and
childlike—she cleans up after him while begging for his approval. Herman can't abandon the
woman who saved his life, no matter how unattractive he finds her. And Masha is always there
to satisfy his obsessive craving for intimacy.
The scenes between Masha and Herman are the
most revealing in "Enemies"; they are convincing expressions of mutual need. The pair make
love as if they were the last two people on earth.
They have learned to cherish each moment
together since they hardly expected to have any.
For the survivors of "Enemies" there is no hiding
in years of psychological bandaging; every emotion is brutally up front. One gets the sense that
something has been carved away against their will,
and that the healing will begin only after they bring
another person as close as is possible.
When Herman promises Masha a Catskills vacation and then waffles at the last minute, she fumes

The renovated Albee plays went up this past
weekend, this year under the name "Theatre Lab"
because Edward Albee did not return this year.
The intersession course was instead taught by
more contemporary names in the theatre world,
such as Tina Howe and Jennifer Warren. The
change in personnel was made as the result of
general dissatisfaction with the course and production of last year's plays. Despite everyone's
best efforts and intentions, however, there still remains a great deal of room for improvement.
To begin with, the plays were performed in what
is typically the stage-right section of the audience.
This was intriguing at first. Upon entering the
theatre, one found the chairs placed on stage for
the patrons to sit in, and lighting stands set up in
various parts of the auditorium, (the standard
lighting was useless in the areas used during the
performance).
After the initial wonder wore off, however, the
realisms hit. It is my guess that this cut down on
the number of available seats, although I could
not say for certain; if it did not, it certainly cut
down severely on the number of good seats, as
the audience's view was obstructed by railings,
lighting racks, and in some cases, shadows. Other
inconveniences included the fact that there was
no miking, so those actors with weaker voices
went largely unheard in the sound-proofed room.
Additionally, the view of the playing area was difficult to see from the lighting booth, and as such,
it was necessary for Jennifer Warren to give
lighting cues from the audience, which was
distracting to those sitting around her.
The evening's production began with Joshua
Coleman's "On the Web," a play about a
gentleman returning home from work on the subway who is suddenly accosted by a youth who fancies himself a comic-book hero of sorts. The play
largely centers around hi assorted rantings and
self-discoveries, played convincingly by Jeff Perlstein, who presented a perfect picture of an 80's
"young tough," though his excessive nervous
laughter seemed inconsistent with the character.
His movement, which at times drew one away
from his lines, was nonetheless energetic and
strong. In fact, Perlstein was able to carry such
strength into the play's more difficult lines, as in
a speech on Greek mythology with phrases like
"hooves of doom," which otherwise might have
fallen flat. The rest of Spiderman's speeches were
also excellent, for that matter, largely due to
stronger writing.
In the background, meanwhile, was Ed Einhorn
as Sal, the late train's other passenger. At the
play's beginning, Einhorn does well with very little, sitting extremely still and shifting his eyes as
the youth jumps around him, periodically spitting
out a line just to pacify the youth. It is when Sal
needs to stand on his own that Einhorn falters.
This may be due in part to the poor flow of the
whole piece—the jumps from exposition to plot
conflict to other plot conflict, etc., were drastic
and heavy-handed—but the speech Sal makes
about his job is well-written. Unfortunately,
Einhorn's whiny tone offered comedy where irony
was needed.
The play's progression from this point is obvious: the boy gets nervous and has a gun, so
naturally he must shoot the innocent passenger.
The fight scene was poorly acted as well, and quite
frankly, I just didn't buy the moment when Spidey
See THEATER, 15

and begins to stalk off. But realization hits her,
and she turns back to Herman. He sighs and
shrugs, blinking slowly, as if to say that he's doing the best he can. Masha is the one who solidifies
the most powerful moments in "Enemies." Her
unblinking desire for truth makes her a genuinely tragic figure when the truth finally hits.
Herman discovers that Tamara (Anjelica
Huston), his wife from Europe, is alive and living in New York. She has returned from the dead,
in a sense: she survived burial in a mass grave,
although neither of the couple's children was so
fortunate. With a bullet still lodged in her hip,
Tamara walks with mock sensuality—she is Herman's safe alternative, the known quantity who
no longer appeals to him in the same complete way
she once did.
Masha wants to be made an "honest woman,"
and Herman obliges at about the same time that
Yadwiga announces she is pregnant with his child.
The idea of three wives has the potential to
degenerate quickly into hijinks, but there's no such
tendency in "Enemies." The film glides on such
a high level that conventional flaws can hardly
reach it.
As things grow tougher for Herman, the
possibility of leaving it all behind grows increasingly attractive. His three wives are more than just
manifestations of a freewheeling libido. He is
responding to the God that has turned its back on
the Jews. "There is no God," he says to Yadwiga, "and if there were, I would defy him."
(This drives Yadwiga to tears, since she has converted to Judaism to win his affections.) Despite
his flaws, Herman is a convincing and empathetic
character: there isn't a hint of malice in him.
The actors in "Enemies— are sensational; they
practically bleed their belief in the material. Silver
and his character are a tight fit, and Huston turns
in another sterling supporting performance. As
Masha, Lena Olin is simply devastating.
Mazursky and co-writer Roger Simon reveal only brief glimpses of the Nazi horrors that plague

with psychological ones, an even more frightening demonstration of the Holocaust's impact on
its battered survivors. There are no crematoriums
or firing squads; instead, memories are triggered

RECORDS

The Jungle Brothers' and Queen Latifah's
Latest Draw Sounds from the Streets
And Lessons from their Peers
by John Park
Last year's De La Soul LP, "Three Feet High
and Rising," defined a sort of pluralism for rap,
where the dookey chain was officially replaced
by Red, Gold, and Green. The DeLas were
mavericks because they didn't wear sweat suits
(though they had funny names) and their attitude
was decidedly mellow. It was a new stance, rooted
firmly in overt racial pride and social independence. Their sound, too, was fresh—muted,
rhythmic drums rattled under cooled-out vocals
and zany samples—and they rapped about
everything from free love to acid-washed jeans.
Two new releases, the Jungle Brothers' "Done
by the Forces of Nature" (Warner Bros.) and
Queen Latifah's "All Hail the Queen"(Tommy
Boy) take the lessons of De La Soul, and prove
that both this new sound and the spirit of the streets
are still going strong.
Though their jungle is in fact Brooklyn, that
doesn't stop the Jungle Brothers from embracing
their African heritage and reviving aspects of Zulu
Nation, founded nine years ago by rap veteran
Afrika Bambaata and the Soul Sonic Force. On
cuts like "Acknowledge Your Own History," "J.
Beez Comin' Through," and "Tribe Vibes," the
Jungle Brothers alternately identify with and update their ancestry, and they invite all takers to
do the same. Their message is clear: they "Forsee
a future of Unity/U and I you and me."
Like Soul II Soul, the Jungle Brothers also
recognize the primal and redemptive powers of
dance, and the frequent chants and exhortations
here to move one's body are not mindless hypes,
but genuine calls for congress on the dance floor.
("No matter what size, shape, or color/We can
jam and enjoy each other.") It's a starkly unified
lyrical vision, and the music backs it with a sleek,
uncluttered sound that recalls the early output of
Tommy Boy Records (as well as the hard grooves
of the Furious Flames). The much-funky "Feelin'
Alright" and — U' Make Me Sweat" should convince all non-believers.
Queen Latifah, meanwhile, has assembled an
impressive panoply of styles—from rap to dancehall to house music—and mixed them with some

attitude, with "All Hail the Queen" the result.
The album's first single, "Dance for Me," was
one of last year's hip-hop rages, and this LP is
brimming with similar treats. Backed by D.J.
Mark the 45 King (who is also perhaps the rap
producer of the year), "All Hail the Queen"
boasts the guest talents of De La Soul, Stetasonic's
Daddy-0, KRS-One, and Monie Love, as well as
a lyrical outlook similar to the Jungle Brothers'.
A lot of the raps on "All Hail the Queen" offer Latifah the chance to put down racism,
violence, and sexism; or to play sly, posturing
characters, as on the goofy "Mama Gave Birth
to the Soul Children." Latifah speaks righteously, and when the mix starts to match her beat with
sampled sound from Sly Stone, Jimi Hendrix, and
even The The, it's a genuine privilege to be a part
of her queendom.
Graham Parker—Human Soul(RCA)
Despite Graham Parker's demonstrated
songwriting ability, there's something oddly unsatisfying about "Human Soul." Certain songs
are superb, as strong as anything of their kind.(4.
special mention should go to "Daddy's A
Postman," a truly hilarous look at the postcardperfect American family.) Parker's political stance
is commendable, as well, though he has jumped
on the bandwagon with "Slash and Burn," his version of the requisite save-the-rainforest song that's
seems destined to show up in some form on every
album this year.
So what's wrong here? A few years ago, this
might have been a groundbreaking record. But the
nagging feeling that "Human Soul" generates,
especially after two or three listenings, is that this
is all-too-familiar territory. Parker clearly owes
a great deal to Elvis Costello; besides their similar
voices, Parker's production style (even his inconsistency) is reminiscent of Elvis's. Still the most
disappointing part of"Human Soul" is the music
itself. The result, in spite of a clearly talented spirit
and solid lyrics, is somewhat tepid.
—Christopher Bonanos
They Might Be Giants—Flood (Elektra)
Lyrically, the major-label debut of They Might

Be Giants is familiar territory. The 18 new songs
on "Flood" are full of the warped little images
that distinguished the group's first two albums.
Typical is "Birdhouse In Your Soul," with lines
like "Not to put too fine a point on it/ say I'm
the only bee in your bonnet/ make a little birdhouse in your soul." Also included is a wonderful cover of "Istanbul (Not Constantinople)," a
song recorded by the Four Lads in 1953 and ideally suited to TMBG's style.
Musically, though, "Flood" is a bit of a departure for the group. In the past, TMBG's

Resourceful, Eccentric NRBQ
Still Potent after All These Years
After over twenty years on
the fringes of commercial success, the band NRBQ seems an
archetype of persistence. The
members of the group remain
loyal to a protean, occasionally !oopy repertoire (several hundred songs strong) and, as their
January 30 performance at
Hammerjack's made clear, they
play it with a peerless rapport.
Not that they flaunt it: The
primary concern at the Hammerjack's show was, as always
with NRBQ, entertainment.
The group ripped through one
rafter-shaking tune after another
("Crazy Like a Fox," "Get
Rhythm," "12 Bar Blues") and
only rarely came up for air, as
in guitarist Al Anderson's

earnest rendition of "Make
Love Not War" early in the
first set.
Yet even the poor sound
system and the dense, raucous
crowd could not mask the
band's remarkable musicianship. Keyboardist Terry Adams
played several rollicking piano
solos during the evening that
evoked such diverse voices as
Jerry Lee Lewis, Sun Ra, and
Thelonious Monk; while
Anderson, a perenially underrated soloist, managed in song
after song to carve his way
through the granite-solid
rhythmic base of drummer Tom
Ardolino and bass player Joey
Sp.1mpinato.
Much of the evening's

material consisted of songs that
have, over time, become
synonymous with NRBQ, particularly material from their
1977 album "NRBQ at Yankee
Stadium" (Mercury). The
group also gave prominent billing to songs from its recent
"Wild Weekend" (Virgin), of
which the delightful "The One
and Only" and "Fraction of
Action" were standouts.
No performance of the New
Rhythm and Blues Quartet
would be complete, however,
without at least one song that
threatened to pervert the mood
of the entire show. "White
Christmas" was the culprit at
