MOVIES

New 'Stella' Falls Short of
Its Predecessor and its Story
by Mark Friedman
In John Erman's "Stella,"
Bette Midler has both a good role
and a potentially great story
before her. Barbara Stanwyck
first played the doting and
anguished Stella Claire in 1939,
in a film (and a performance) that
many now consider a classic. Yet
from the evidence of the new
"Stella," one is led to suspect
that both Erman and Midler were
prepared to ride on the coattails
of the earlier film.
The choppy storyline begins as
Stella is made pregnant by a
young medical student (Stephen
Collins), who agrees to do the
right thing and marry her. She
elects to raise the child herself,

however, and after Jenny is born,
Stella's main objective in life appears to be making her happy.
Yet the spectre of father always
lingers. Jenny meets her wellsituated father repeatedly over the
years (illustrated in a time-elapsed
series of ice cream sundae lunches) and grows up before the audience's eyes. Although Jenny is
living under her mother's roof,
the film glosses over roughly a
dozen years of her life (in the
aforementioned scene) with next
to no mention of Stella. Whatever
insight we might gain from seeing them "grow up" together is
blacked out.
Even in Jenny's early years
(presumably before she started
going out for ice cream), the rap-

port between she and Stella seems
cliched. Though Stella's love may
indeed be perdurable and genuine, it comes across as nothing
special: Stella brushes Jenny's
hair, puts on her pretty dresses
and Mary Jane shoes, etc.
When Jenny grows up, she no
longer seems very appealing. The
adolescent
Jenny
(Trini
Alvarado) spends most of her
time looking physically exhausted, and she certainly isn't
very lovable—a quality that
would make Stella's crude,
down-home affections at least
plausible, if not necessarily likely. By the time Jenny is grown,
nonetheless, she doesn't seem
worth fighting for any longer, at
least to the audience.

CONCERTS

Eccentric NRBQ Still Potent
sung by drummer Ardolino
(who does not usually sing) to
the accompaniment of Anderson's soft,jazzy guitar fills. Ardolino performed the tune absolutely deadpan, his eyes on
the ceiling as if her were expecting Kris Kringle himself to appear. Meanwhile, Adams
jumped onto the drum riser and
began banging gleefully on Ardolino's kit, against the beat.
This sort of excursion into
craziness has made NRBQ's
live performances legendary.
Coupled with the band's
refreshing approach to concert
programming—Adams chooses
the evening's program sponat
each
taneously
performance—it brings both excitement and a chance of col-

lapse to every NRBQ show.
The Hammerjack's performance witnessed a little of both.
Although "White Christmas"
was zanily inspired, some of
Adams' other choices at show's
end ("Green Lights," "Ridin'
in My Car") seemed too conventional, lacking in nerve. One
of the band's agile, complex instrumentals would have been a
welcome substitute.
Despite the loss of steam at
the end, the band's set and two
encores were clean, energetic,
and deceptively nuanced. Part
of NRBQ's appeal is the apparent ease with which they
tackle so many musical idioms;
nothing seems beyond the
players' technical or emotional
range. Unfortunately, that

mutable quality has also been a
party to the Quartet's commercial demise; one suspects that
radio programmers (and many
potential fans) simply don't
know what to make of their eccentric musical aesthetic.
As their performances and
their records attest, however,
the New Rhythm and Blues
Quartet isn't eager to be
pigeonholed artistically. The
group has survived two decades
without serious threat to its
schizophrenic Muse, and loyal
listeners have reaped the
benefits. No other band, to my
knowledge, has so many
musical resources at its fingertips, or wields them so
shrewdly.
—T.H. Kern

Still, an enormous fight is the
conclusion to it all. Wealthy John
(of upstate New York) and
cosmetic-toting Stella (of upper
middle Nowheresville) face off
for their daughter's lovetorn affections. Curiously, there isn't an
ounce of tension in these scenes:
Both parents are so accomodating
to Jenny that they come across as
merely bland and uncommitted.
The filmmakers, unfortunately, are committed in a different
way. Throughout "Stella" there
are constant (and not very subtle)
shifts of contrast, from Stella's
sparse furniture and clothes to the
pomp and elegance of the father's
surroundings. The carrot has
been mounted on the stick for
Jenny, one would assume, but
"Stella" tries repeatedly to lure
the au6ience into its materialist
mindset. It's difficult not to feel
for Stella: not only is she poor
and in danger of losing her
daughter, her own film is against
her, as well.
At the same time, Midler often
comes close to swallowing the entire picture with her presence.
Stella Claire is a jewel of a role,
and Midler knows it. In her

euphoria to play it faithfully, she
practically strangles the character
to death. She is constantly talking too loudly, slamming doors,
jumping onto bars, and the like,
threatening at times to swamp the
entire picture.
This is compounded by director John Erman's weighty
dramatic atmosphere, which
seeks to add emotional intensity
where none is necessary or even
possible. When Stella decides to
have her child alone, early in the
film, the audience is supposed to
accept her decision as fatalistic:
Stella is destined to have an arduous, unfulfilling life. The hitch
is, if you don't buy Midler's
posturing—Erman
tries
desperately to ensure that you
do—the rest of "Stella" is utterly predictable.
Despite all this, however,

Midler is perfectly cast. It's a
testimony to her ability that she
navigates Robert Getchell's
tiresome screenplay so adroitly.
Her Stella is loud, brash, and unself-conscious, so much so that
she all but eclipses the other performances in the film.(Even Erman seems intimidated by her
presence, choosing to shoot her
at a distance rather than in
close-up.)
It remains clear, even after
Midler has blazed across the
screen and the credits have rolled, that somewhere in "Stella"
lies a great story. Not a great
script, necessarily, but a story.
The latest version of "Stella"
suggests that Erman and Midler
thought so, too, but that they expected the story to do their dirty
work for them.

Screenplay by Robert Getchell

THEATER, from 14
comes back to hug Sal's body; it was corny and
felt like a hammer pounding in a message.
Next came the first of the evening's four
monologues, "Body Parts," which was written
by Andrew Bragen (also actor in the show). The
monologue focused on a grandmother reminiscing on her late husband and their experiences in
growing old. But in the short time it went on, it
explored the fear of technology, sex after sixty,
romance, antagonism in marriage, fear of
lonliness, and a host of other subjects. Bragen's
writing is bright, funny, and strong, and Nancy
Werner's performance as Eula was nothing less
than endearing. She did little more than sit in a
rocking chair and point her finger to Heaven, but
her voice was all she really needed. It made "Body
Parts" the best part of the evening.
Then came another monologue, "Rhiannon's
Bane," written by Douglas Barre, also an actor,
and performed by Robin Brillante. The segment
concerned a teenager making a trip to the free
clinic for the obvious and her explanation to the
invisible doctor (receptionist? nurse?) about why

she is taking the step that she is. Perhaps it's just
that it is a man writing about a woman's anxiety
before an abortion, perhaps not, but this just didn't
work well at all, particularly in the wake of
something as fresh as "Body Parts."
The idea is hackneyed, and Barre handles it
vaguely. After all, this woman is planning to have
an abortion, yet she tells a story (again from Greek
mythology) about a goddess punished for killing
her baby, then says that she didn't want to feel
like she was killing hers. Confusing. Even given
that poetic license, however, neither Barre's
writing nor Brillante's performance convinced me
that this character would delve deeply into Greek
mythology to explain her own pregnancy.
The segment did have one terrific aspect,
however: Brillante's face. For whatever her words
lacked, her face supplied: a wrinkled brow and
pursed smirk for naive confusion, a slight tilt for
shame or embarrassment. While these devices
couldn't always drag the writing up onto a higher
level, her expressions, at least, stood far enough
above the text to be noteworthy.

Theatre Lab's Highs and Lows
THEATER, from 15
Then came "Volunteers," David Dudley's play
about three men in a government drug testing experiment. Douglas Barre played the neophyte
Green to comic excellence, hitting all the whines
just right, but rarely letting them go too far, prodding the other two men (Red in particular) just
the right amount. Andrew Bragen played the
worldly irate Red, whose main goal seemed to be
getting free food, a free place to stay, and his
money. While the role was small, Bragen filled
it well, turning otherwise gratuitous cursing into
effective punctuation in the scenes. Unfortunately, the character itself was the weakest of the three,
serving as the explainer and mediator of the other
two.
But when Blue (Josh Coleman) entered in the
first scene, it was as if electricity were suddenly
pumped onto the stage. He wore his character like
most people wear an old coat—he was comfortable, and knew exactly how to wear it to make
it look good. You really believed that he was
brain-fried from too many previous experiments.
While most actors would use nervous tics to flush
out a character, Coleman used them as explanations of his own. His tapping fingers and rubbing
hands were expressions both of drug abuse and
of fear—fear of going outside, fear of staying in,
and fear of the power of the other two men over
him, for if anyone leaves or loses control of
himself, we were told, the experiment is off.
The three worked together beautifully, so well
in fact that it became tough to say if it was good
acting or good writing or both. Green and Red
seemed to rely on Blue for information, and Blue
on them as well, though the audience was never
told what for. By the third scene, the audience
knew that they'd been cooped up in that room for
three weeks, watching the same movies, building
forced comradery, eating Twinkies, smoking
dope, and getting on each others' nerves. In one
scene, Green badgered Red by counting randomly while Red did sit-ups. Red lost count of how
many he'd done, and nearly punched Green until
Blue reminded him of the violence clause in the
experiment agreement. Later in the same scene,
however, in a beautifully comic reprisal, Green
began banging his head against the wall in frusration, and Red, realizing that the experiment and
his paycheck would be cancelled, began counting
randomly, hoping Green would lose track of how
many times he had hit himself.
Unfortunately, Dudley needed maybe one more
scene to pull off the ending. When Blue slammed
his way out of the experiment, it felt as though
the tables had turned too quickly and too obviously

for a play of this intelligence. Something is missing, and while the ending works, given what
preceded it, it could work better.
After intermission, Elin Hilderbrand came out
and performed Salvatore Zannino's "Pageant.' In
it, Aria Alexander is about to go out for the evening wear segment of a beauty pageant and in an
especially inane speech, she comments on her
looks in a mirror. Hildebrand had only 45 seconds
to save herself from the mire of the writing and
the hurried miming of make-up application, and
unfortunately, it just wasn't enough time. She was
forced to deliver lines that begin with "Oh, Lynda Carter," and "Oh, Liz Taylor" and ended by
insulting these actresses in ways that were neither
clever nor poignant in terms of her character. The
piece had no apparent purpose, except to waste
Hilderbrand's considerable talent.
The fourth and final monologue, "American
Geisha," was written and performed by Kerry
Tesoriero. It concerned a stock person at a clothing
store as she (rather amorously) considered a
female co-worker. Tesoriero swayed and stared
and spoke deeply, offering an erotic tension so
intense that I thought the two women were
homosexual. The writing was tremendous, and the
images Tesoriero created accentuated the tones she
established, one such image being the "faux-lizard
sling-gack pumps, green" that surfaced at just the
right moments. Toward the end, however,
Tesoriero introduces the co-worker's boyfriend—
are these merely voiced mental musings? Still, as
in the case of "Volunteers," strong acting
throughout, and strong writing that paled towards
the end.
The final piece of the evening was Nathan Potter's "Rubber Bullets." Jason Katz played Alex,
a cleaning man who works in a bar owned by an
alcoholic, wife-beating jerk named Dennis (Carl
Larkin). Alex is friendly with the bartender, Lenny
(Raymond Parungoa), who offers advice on Alex's
affections for Dennis's wife, Cara. Alex is essentially a milquetoast who lets himself be bullied,
humors himself, and tries to humor others by offering artistic criticism on Martin Scorcese's film
"Taxi Driver" (based on notes no doubt taken
in Linda Benn's film class last semester). When
Alex manages to get a gun away from a mugger
(the second one he has encountered that day), he
becomes filled with delusions of changing his life
by killing Dennis and stealing Cara away. In the
end of course, he can't go through with it, and
the play ends largely the way it begins.
Jason Katz truimphs over very difficult material
in this play, giving a depth to his character that
is lacking in the other three performers. He

manages to make even the most awkward scenes
work as best they might(including Alex's impersonation of Robert DeNiro's psychotic
confrontation with his mirror in Taxi Driver).
Raymond Parungao also does an admirable job
with his material as Lenny, but unfortunately, he
just doesn't deliver the amount of realism that Katz
does—some of his lines are just too unreal to be
delivered well. Carl Latkin as the abusive, weighttrained Dennis moved too stiffly and spoke too
deliberately to be intimidating, but moreover his
character was just inconsistent, though this is a
flaw in the writing. For example, told that his wife
has cheated on him, why doesn't he beat her
soundly when he has the chance? We are told he
has done this before, for less of a reason. Julia
Ro's character suffers from many of the same
problems—if she is so rational and determined to
stay with her husband, why does his display of
uncaring send her to Alex's apartment? And if she
isn't intelligent enough to have left her husband
or to get help for him, or to understand Alex's
comments on the movie, then how is she able to
figure out Alex's scheme—even Lenny isn't that
bad a liar. She knows that killing is crazy, but
doesn't realize cheating on her physically abusive
husband is crazy. Unfortunately, these inconsistencies proved to be too much for Ro who was
believable scene to scene, but not as a whole
character.
But the root of the problems with the acting stem
from the play itself. Apart from the inconsistent

characters mentioned above and the obviously
plagarized elements from Taxi Driver, the movement of the play just doesn't work. Potter
establishes such extreme characters at the beginning of the play that he has nowhere to take them
but to mediocrity. Alex is so spineless that the gun
might have the legitimate ability to send him over
the deep end and kill Dennis, but he doesn't. Dennis is so self-centered and ill-tempered that realizing that Alex has cuckolded him would be enough
reason for him to kill Alex when he gets the chance.
But he doesn't. And the scene ot the two men
about to kill each other playing with a real gun
should be enough to make even someone as
unintelligent as Cara realize that the two men are
dangerous, but it doesn't. On top of which is the,.
question of the gun itself. One of the first things
a writer is told is an old adage by Chekov, which
states, "if you put a gun on the wall in Act I, you'd
better have used it by Act V." Potter sets himself
up with a damned-if-you-do, damned-if-you-don't
situation. If Alex does kill Dennis, or vice-versa,
then that's too obvious. But because the gun never
gets used, the audience is left feeling unfulfilled,
as though they have just watched nothing change.
The intersession program did an admirable job
in the time they had to work in. But the limitation of time, added to the already disorienting notion of not performing on stage may have proven
to be too much, for, in many cases, they seemed
to fall short of polished work.

ENEMIES,

In the 1990's, the sexually transmitted disease that will make the
front page of "Time" magazine and dominate the science sections
of newspapers is that caused by the Human Papilloma Virus. As with
other sexuallly transmitted diseases, infection rates are highest among
adolescents and college students. A study done at the University of
Washington (Seattle) showed that 17 percent of sexuallly active
women were infected with HPV. At Hopkins, approximately ten percent of students have some evidence of HPV infection.
There are over 50 strains of this virus. Some strains typically cause
warts on the skin. Other strains cause warts to develop anywhere
on or in the male or female genital tract. Warts may develop on the
penis or scrotum or on the vulva, in the vagina or on the cervix.
Both males and females can develop warts around the anus even if
they do not engage in anal intercourse. Visible warts usually develop
in two-thirds of individuals who have intercourse with an infected
partner. The time from infection to the appearance of visible warts

by Alan Joffe
Medical Director, Student Health Clinic
The two most prevalent sexually transmitted diseases on college
campuses today, Johns Hopkins University included, are Chlamydia
Trachomatis and Human Papillorna Virus (HPV). Over the last
decade, the symptoms, complications and treatment for chlamidial
infections have been well delineated. For HPV infection, optimum
identification and treatment strategies have only begun to emerge.
Chlamydia Trachomatis is an organism that can only live within
cells of the body. It most commonly infects genital tract cells but
can infect other areas as well. Approximately ten percent of sexually active college students get this infection; nationwide, infection rates
are highest among people 15-24 years of age.
Symptoms of infection usually develop within two weeks of exposure to this organism. Among males, the urethra is most commonly
involved. Typically, students complain of discharge from the penis
and/or burning when they urinate. However, many infected males
may have no symptoms whatsoever yet are still capable of transmitting the infection to their partner.
For females, the most common site of infection is the cervix; women
may seek treatment for a vaginal discharge. However, since this
organism can also infect the urethra, a woman may experience burning when she urinates. This symptom is also experienced by women

with a bladder infection; hence, women who seek treatment at the

organism is a regular part of annual gynecologic exams at the Clinic.
Even though the symptoms of this infection are often mild or even
nonexistent, the consequences of untreated infections can be
devastating, especially for women. This organism can gain access
to the uterus and fallopian tubes, setting up an intense inflammation
that can result in scarring which leads to infertility and/or an increased
risk for ectopic pregnancy (an abnormal pregnancy in which the fertilized egg grows in the fallopian tube rather than the uterus.) Fortunately, ther are several inexpensive tests that can identify individuals
even if thay have no symptoms. All of these techniques are available
through the Student Health Clinic.
Once an infection is detected, treatment is relatively simple. A student need only take doxycycline, tetracycline, or erythromycin for
seven to ten days. Successful treatment, and limitation of spread of
this organism, requires notification of all recent sex partners. Unfortunately, infection does not confer immunity: one can be infected

Association is a nonprofit
education organization founded in 1957 to enable young
people to participate in the
management of wilderness
areas and natural resources.
More than 15,000 young men
and women have participated

past 32 years.
Programs are carried out in
cooperation with federal agencies including the National
Park Service, the U.S. Forest
Service, the Bureau of Land
Management, and the U.S.
Fish and Wildlife Service. The
SCA also contributes to conservation efforts at many state
and local natural resource
areas across the country.

by Eric Ruck
Throughout history, and
especially in the '50s, people
have asked the question, why do
fools fall in love? Why indeed?
Blessed with a university full of
experts on a variety of
disciplines, we took this question
to the streets, to Ames, Gilman
and Shaffer halls, and other
places less mentionable so we
could bring this feature to you for
Valentine's Day. The following
are the best responses. Enjoy.
"I think it's a defense against
ego boundaries. When you grow
up you realize that you have
limitations, that what you think
isn't what other people think. It's
an attempt at changing that.
When you fall in love you slacken
ego boundaries.
Falling in love is a way of connecting yourself with the world."
—Walter Harley, psychology
grad student

varies greatly, from six weeks to eight months.
A decade ago, warts were considered a problem mainly because
they were unsightly. However, recent research has established a link
between HPV infection and the development of cancer of the cervix
in women. This is not to say that any woman with genital warts will
develop cervical cancer. Rather, sexually active women with HPV
infection appear to be at higher risk for developing cervical cancer
than sexually active women who do not have such an infection. The
magnitude and nature of the risk has yet to be worked out. A piece
of the puzzle appears to be that certain strains of HPV that cause
genital warts have the capability of transforming normal cells into
cancerous cells whereas other strains of genital HPV do not. It is
also likely that other factors—as yet unidentified—play a role.
Any male who has any concerns that he has genital warts should
seek care at the Student Health Clinic. Those who have been told
by their sex partners that they are infected should seek care even
if they personally cannot detect any warts.
We make this recommendation because many males may have infection that can only be detected through use of a magnifying glass
and a vinegar wash.
Fifty to sixty percent of women with warts on their external genitalia
will also have cervical infection. However, only three to six percent
of women with cervical HPV infection will have external genital
warts. Hence, use of a PAP smear as a regular component of the
annual gynecologic exam has become more critical than ever. The
most common cause of a persistently abnormal PAP smear among
college women is the presence of HPV infection. Hence, women
whose PAP smears remain abnormal even after they receive treatment for other sexually transmitted diseases, will likely require further evaluation, usually by a gynecologist at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital. This is because physicians who look at PAP smears cannot readily distinguish between changes associated with HPV infection and those seen in early cervical cancer.
Treatment of external genital warts usually consists of applications
of a resin called podophyllin or liquid nitrogen. Depending on the
size of the wart, six or seven treatments, one week apart, are often
needed. Warts in the vagina or penis or on the cervix require more
specialized treatment, usually by a gynecologist or urologist. Because
the DNA from the wart virus can be incorporated into normal human
cells, HPV infections can persist and be very difficult to treat. Since
infection with one strain does not confer immunity against other
strains, one can be infected multiple times. It also appears that one
can be reinfected with the same strain even after successful treatment. As with any sexually transmitted infection, notification and
treatment of sex partners is critical.
How do you protect yourself against infection? Again, condoms
used with spermicides offer the best protection. Condoms offer a
mechanical barrier of protection while the active ingredient in spermicides (nonxyno1-9) appears capable of killing the wart virus. Use
of condoms will also decrease your risk of getting AIDS. In many
parts of the world, condoms are the primary means of contraception; among the Japanese, almost two-thirds of sexually active males
regularly use condoms. If we are to stem the • epidemic of sexually
transmitted diseases in the United States, we need to follow their lead.

Enfield shatters scoring mark
Junior reaches 1,236 points as Jays top Swarthmore
With a playoff bid on the line,
the Jays have been as unpredictable as recent developments in
the Soviet Union. Hopkins began
February trailing second-place
Widener by one game in the
MAC Southeastern Division and
facing a tough league foe, Ursinus, on the road. Coach Bill
Nelson was asked before the
game whether Hopkins was
favored to win. "Are you kidding? They beat us down here fat
Hopkins] last time!" Had Nelson
known that his leading scorer,
Andy Enfield, would be held to
eleven points, he would have
been even more concerned than
coaches usually are in such situations. The Jays came through,
however, to beat Ursinus 75-72
with a balanced offensive attack,
setting up a showdown for second
with Widener.
The Widener game began with
a strong defensive effort and a
precisely run offense. Unfortunately for Hopkins, both were
put forth by Widener, who quickly went up 10-0. A Dick Vitalelike feeling emanated throughout
the arena: Get a T.O., baby—
which Nelson did to try to help
the Jays figure out how to break
Widener's zone defense.
The results, however, were
similar to those reaped if a boxer switched from a traditional
right-handed stance to southpaw
in attempting to outpoint Mike
Tyson. By the time the half ended, the Jays were down 30-13. To
say they were struggling on offense would be quite an
understatement.

Widener came in with a simple but calculated game plan to
stop Hopkins and proceeded to
execute it to perfection. On offense, they played a slow-down
game, running the 45-second shot
clock down to 10 practically
every offensive trip. At that moment, the Widener coach would
yell "Ten!" and one of the
Widener guards would look to
drive and create. Amazingly,
Widener was able to get good
shots off, even with the shot clock
running down, and finished the
game 23-for-44 for 52 percent.
On defense they played a zone
that extended out to the threepoint circle and retracted back into the lane with astonishing
celerity. The Jays tried their usual
zone-breaking scheme by putting
Enfield and Jay Gangemi just outside the three-point circle, and
Bill Zahn on the baseline. Zahn,
however, wasn't able to connect
on his first three attempts from
that location and the Widener
guards and forwards were very
quick to jump out on Enfield
whenever he touched the ball.
This occasionally left Gangemi
open, who had hit 46 percent of
his three-pointers on the season.
But this wasn't to be his night,
unless there were recent job
openings in the bricklaying industry, as Gangemi was only able
to connect on three of twelve
treys and three of fourteen shots
overall, finishing with nine
points. The rest of the Jays'
regulars got similar results,
hoisting up 34 shots and connecting on only 12.
Widener's zone was also effective in keeping Hopkins off the

One Fan's View:

In defense of an
unappreciated art

boards, as three or four Jays were
usually on the perimeter when
shots were attempted. The basic
problem, though, was Hopkins'
lack of a third outside shooter to
break the zone. With point guard
Dave Eikenberg, whose main
jobs are to play tough defense,
run the offense, and distribute the
ball, at the top of the key,
Widener's guards were able to
leave him open for the most part
and key on Enfield. In this instance Eikenberg's unwillingness
to launch the three-pointer seemed to limit Hopkins' attack. In addition, Eikenberg had an uncharacteristic five turnovers and
only three assists. Hopkins was
also unable to get the ball inside
the zone either by inlet passes or
penetration. On several occasions
Eikenberg was able to penetrate,
but rather than breaking down the
defense he found himself surrounded by Widener players with
no one to pass the ball to.
Hopkins was able to cut the
lead to single digits after
Gangemi connected on three treys
early in the second half, but the
Jays were never able to seriously threaten Widener after that,
losing by the final score of 60-50.
Enfield was unable to get untracked, finishing with 10 points
(which led the team) on 4-9
shooting. Widener's coach implored his players to be conscious
of Enfield's location at all times.
During every timeout he could be
heard saying, "Know where Enfield is! Know where Enfield is!"

NEWS-LETTER/21

Squash tops Haverford
Travels to Yale for Howe Cup

Swimmers prepare for'IAA's

by Jerry Irvine

Leave Wednesday for championships
by Michele Royce
On Saturday, January 27, the
Hopkins swim team hosted
American University, which
featured Olympic bronze medal
winner Sergio Lopez of Spain.
The men's meet was very close,
as Hopkins' well-roundedness
shone through, with a final score
of 129 to 110 on the side of
American. Hopkins dominated
men's diving, as junior Steve
Giangrandi continued his streak
of good performances by taking
the top place on both the one and
three meter boards. Senior Mike
Dear supplemented this by taking
second place on both boards.
Other individual winners for the
Jays were senior Chris Hussin in
the 200 yard Backstroke, with a
time of 2:02.94, and freshman
Jim Quinn in the 200 Breaststroke
in 2:15.47. The Hopkins 400
Free Relay Team of seniors Mike
Costa and John Hsu,junior Steve

Muchow, and freshman Aaron
Osborne brought the race home
in 3:16.00, over 5 seconds ahead
of the second place team. And in
the 200 yard Freestyle,
American's Lopez set a new pool
record of 1:41.66.
The women also performed
well, although the final score was
not as even, with American taking 137 points to Hopkins' 97.
Sophomore Jill Christiensen earned her place on the Hopkins
women's national team by scoring 383.62 points on the 1 meter
springboard, and took first place
in the process. Sophomore
Stephanie Dengler ran away with
the race in the 1650 yard
Freestyle, finishing with a time
of 18:31.00—more than a minute
and a half ahead of American's
first swimmer. And senior cocaptain Mary Price took first
place in the 50 yard Freestyle
with a time of 26.00 seconds. The
Lady Jays' 400 Free Relay team

of Price, freshman Danielle Bird,
junior Melanie Chellman, and
senior Laura Carroll matched the
accomplishment of their male
counterpart by winning the race
with a time of 3:51.15.
The following Saturday,
February 3, Hopkins met the
team from Gettysburg College in
one of the biggest rivalries of the
year. The Hopkins men fared extremely well and finished with a
final score of 131 to Gettysburg's
72. Sophomore Lars Hondorf
was a double winner, taking the
top place in the 200 yard
Freestyle with a time of 1:48.07
and in the 500 yard Freestyle in
4:58.08. Senior co-captain Mark
Rhoads was another of the team's
several individual winners, winning the 100 yard Backstroke by
touching the wall in 56.36
seconds.
While the women were unable
to defeat the larger team from
Gettysburg College, the final

score being 116 for Gettysburg to
84 for Hopkins, there were some
extraordinary performances by
several of the Jays. Senior Mary
Price, in her last collegiate dual
meet, captured first places in both
the 50 and the 100 yard Freestyle
events, with times of 25.96 and
56.94 respectively. With the
absence of freshman Anne Hunt
due to illness, sophomore Betsy
Batchelor took control of the 100
yard Breaststroke and touched out
the second place competitor from
American by 22 one hundredths
of a second, finishing with a time
of 1:11.55. The happiest moment
of the meet came when junior cocaptain Amy Parke, who also was
in her last collegiate dual meet,
beat the qualifying standard in the
200 yard Backstroke with a time
of 2:16.85. In the spirit of true
cooperation, Gettysburg's head
coach agreed to allow Parke and
opponent Amy Shelden, who had
already qualified in the event,
to swim a 200 yard race while the
rest of the field finished at the 100
yard mark. The competition that
Shelden provided allowed Parke
to find those extra few tenths of
a second, which is what she had
previously missed the cut by. And
so one more person is headed to
Williams College in March for
Division III NCAA's.
On Wednesday, February 14,
the team leaves for St. Louis to
compete in the University
Athletic Association conference
championships at Washington
University, as both teams try to
defend their championships of
last year.

an extremely demanding schedule, featuring numerous Division I teams.

The women's squash team
defeated Haverford 7-2, avenging
a loss to the Fords earlier in the
season. The win raises the
squad's record to 2-5 and gives
the team momentum entering the
final tournament of the year, the
Howe Cup.
The squad will be competing in
the fourth division at the Howe
Cup for the second year running.
The tournament, held at Yale, is
considered the equivalent of the
national championships for collegiate squash. The team is very
young, carrying only one senior.
Also, the team aquired Frank and
Nancy Cushman as its two new
head coaches. They both expressed optimism regarding the upcoming tournament. "The team
finished third last year in the same
division," said Frank Cushman.
"We hope to do at least that well
this year, hopefully we can improve upon that standing."
The team is led by senior
Kathryn Ng, who the coaches attribute much of the teams improvement and success. Said
Frank Cushman, "She's been the
number one or two player all
year, and has led by example at
the practices and matches with
her hard work." Mr. Cushman
also stated that the entire lineup
had improved a great deal over
the course of the year and was
overall a very balanced squad.
"Anyone of the players can beat
another on a given day. That type
of inner competition is invaluable
in trying to improve and build a
strong program."
Other players making the trip
to the Howe Cup are Tara Dorr,
Karen Phillips, Natasha Dupont,
Jessica Troppe, Laura Gaffney,
Michelle Steindecker, Rosey
DaCosta,
and
Cristina
VanRiesenfelder.
The team opened the season
with a closely contested defeat at
the hands of Haverford. They

then travelled to Wesleyan in
Connecticut for a weekend tournament against Bates, Hamilton,
Wesleyan, and Cornell. Although
the competition was tough the
team came away with an uplifting
victory over Cornell. "You get
a lot out of tournaments because
the competition is so tough and
you're playing more than once a
day," stated freshman Jill Litt.
The team followed the tournament with defeats at the hands of
powerhouse Penn and Franklin &
Marshall. The last match against
Haverford was a much needed
victory against a tough Haverford
team. Said sophomore Rosy
DaCosta, "The last Haverford
match showed how much we've
improved over the course of the
season."
The team has worked hard
throughout the season, which
began in November, but have had
difficulty due to the tough competition and lack of experience.
Said sophomore Rosy DaCosta,
"Playing a nationally ranked
team like Franklin & Marshall
can be demoralizing, but at the
same time it is a very valuable
learning experience to play
against such good competition."
Many of Hopkins opponents
this year have players who have
been playing squash for many
years. In addition, most of the op-posing schools have several
juniors and seniors, in stark contrast to the Hopkins squad which
besides being comprised mostly
of freshmen and sophomores also
carries many newcomers to the
game of squash. Coach Frank
Cushman sees this youth movement as a positive aspect of the
team. "The hard work and good
attitude the team has carried with
them all year will definetly pay
off in the years to come. The fact
that the players are so young
makes me very positive about the
trend the team is taking for the
future."

Praise for the pencil pushers
A writer on the most-read section
JOSH, from 20
Exceptional sportswriting exists, and deserves as much credit
as exceptional writing in any
other form of journalism. In
America today, where more people read the sports section than
read the first section, the value of
talented sportswriters cannot be
understated.
Sports are integral to American

culture. As Jacques Barzun wrote
in "God's Country and Mine,"
"Whoever wants to know the
heart and mind of America had
better learn baseball." The same
could be said of football or
basketball. America is a country
full of athletes and fans, and the
sportswriter is the interpreter of
the games.
Red Smith said his "goal was
to entertain . . . and capture the

grace and drama and beauty and
humor." A sportswriter's role is
not to place athletes on Mount
Olympus and offer sacrifices nor
to write cliche-ridden babble. His
role is to entertain and educate,
as any journalist should, for
sportswriting is only as limited as
a sportswriter's ability.
